One Piece. I thought the story was great in the beginning. I think at the time, I was watching so many anime that I just put it on the back burner. Now, even catching glimpses of it, the pacing seems antiquated. The art style is off-putting to me, like some characters are way too cartoony for my taste. And honestly, at this point in my life, I ain't watching all that

I could see that God wanted to teach Satan a lesson but at the same time it does seem that he kinda gave up on the world at the end. I guess it plays into the whole idea of God having destroyed the world twice before and wouldn't do it again, so it was on us but we weren't winning that fight

The context is easy to understand, and it was an incredibly beautiful anime from start to finish. The issue for me is it escalated so much and so quickly to get such a simple thing across. So the entire world had to be obliterated just so that Satan could realize he cared for his friend, who essentially expressed his care for Satan since they were kids? God could have intervened at any point before then, and in many different ways, I'm sure, but nah, let's just see how bad things get first. It was almost comedic

I personally would finish a chapter, then put it out. I think that would be the best for you and the audience. Your art is amazing, and as long as the story is good, you'll build a following. Once you put it out, you might feel like you need to keep up that momentum, but you shouldn't rush because then you might lose some of that great quality. Take your time with it

Honest opinion. If you're putting out quality work like that, I wouldn't care how long it took. I dont think anyone will be pressed about your release schedule if you put it out as it's just you, so if that's what you're worried about, I wouldn't.

I guess it would depend on the language, but Google Translate is historically known for giving some very weird translations between languages. I agree and disagree. Yes, people talk and write every day, but not at the level it would take describe as much detail in a single panel of most manga. In fact, that type of writing is usually discouraged in most schools and professions unless one is enrolled in a creative writing course. Your example is almost like saying everyone can evoke the same emotion as Stephen King does when writing a horror novel because we do it every day. Casual conversation isn't the same because people get the gist of things through commonality, not because it's a high level.

(BTW, this isn't an attack, and I agree with art being harder, but not everyone can articulate what their mind is perceiving, in that way, I find art is an easier medium than writing.)

As someone who has sold on whatnot and definitely spent a lot on the platform, I can tell you there are a lot of scams, but there are also a lot of good sellers on there as well. I was probably one of the more hated sellers due to the fact that I valued the cards way less than what the market was, but that was due to the fact that I needed money. Many of those streamers, with hundreds of viewers, have been there a while are dependent upon those sales. They are, in fact, resellers. I often avoided them unless there was a giveaway I could win or something like that. The key thing is knowing what you want and knowing its price. When streaming, or watching always have your computer and phone with you to have tcgplayer up so you don't get ripped off and if you're in a bidding war know where to stop where you're actually saving because shipping can still hurt. Also, avoid any huge giveaways, like a PS5, Ferrari (yes, I've seen that before), etc. because you're going to end up wasting a lot of money, win or lose

Edit: Tl;dr: Know what you want, and don't buy into gimmicks

Im an old fool, so it's painful for me to try to put my arm in that position, but I always recommend having a model or doing it yourself to get the idea of how it should look. Overall, you've got talent and are better than many I've seen. Keep up the good work
